Dear Ms. Oom,
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violation identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff responsibilities
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section • (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all the following activities:
• (a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home
care. Social service workers shall work directly with
the children, their families, and other relevant
individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service
plans for the children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that the foster care worker failed to transport a youth’s
medication to the youth’s new location. Youth was without
medication for approximately 16 days.
Investigation The Chief Administrator was notified via telephone of the
complaint on 03/18/24 and that a special investigation has
been initiated.
The Chief Administrator acknowledged Youth A had not received
his medications when he was transferred from Wolverine Center
to Wayne County Juvenile Detention Center, (JDC). The Chief
Administrator referred me to the agency worker who is the case
worker for Youth A.
Staff 1, the agency case worker, was interviewed via phone
on 03/27/24. Staff 1 reported Youth A was removed from the care
of Wolverine Center on 02/25/24. Staff 1 reported she understood
Youth A was without medications until approximately 03/14/24.
Staff 1 reported she was unaware that it was the responsibility of
DA Blodgett to get Youth A’s medications to JDC. Staff 1 reported
Wolverine Center eventually forwarded the medications to JDC.
Staff 1 reported on 03/07/24 it was learned from another DHHS
Worker that Youth A did not have his medications. Staff 1 reported
she then spoke with the director of JDC who informed her they
would not accept medications from Wolverine Center. Staff 1
reported she eventually gained a one time permission from the
JDC Director to accept the medications for Youth A.
2

The Chief Administrator, Foster Care Program Supervisor
and Staff 1 were interviewed jointly via telephone on 05/17/24.
The Chief Administrator reported she knew of the medication
issue and thought it was the responsibility of Wolverine Center to
transfer Youth A’s medication to JDC. When the Chief
Administrator obtained knowledge on 03/07/24 that the
medications had not been transferred to JDC she gave a directive
to the Foster Care Program Supervisor that the agency needed to
get the medications to JDC.
The Foster Care Program Supervisor reported the agency did not
know Youth A’s medications had not been transferred to JDC until
03/07/24 when another DHHS Worker. notified the agency that
Youth A had been without his medications. The Foster Care
Supervisor reported she had assumed Wolverine Center had
transferred Youth A’s medications to JDC when he entered the
facility on 02/25/24.
Staff 1 reiterated information she had given during the 03/27/24
interview, specifically that on 03/07/24, when it was learned that
Youth A had not received his medication, she contacted the JDC
Director who initially refused to accept medications from
Wolverine Center but relented and allowed this to occur.
Youth A was interviewed on 03/07/24 during investigation
2024SIC0001225. A review of this related investigation indicates
Youth A was interviewed by Consultant 3. Youth A reported at that
time he had not received his medications.
On 05/07/24, the DCWL Licensing Consultant 1 for JDC, emailed
medical information for Youth A per my request.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
• A document titled, “Wayne County Juvenile Detention
Facility Special Services Consult Form”, documents that
JDC received from a Wolverine Center staff, Youth A’s
medication on 03/14/24.
• Youth A’s case file: The file documents that Youth A was
discharged from Wolverine Center on 02/25/24 and entered
JDC on the same date.
• There is not a documented social work contact indicating
Staff 1 had spoken with the JDC Director.
• A review of an Updated Service Plan dated 03/14/24
documents that Youth A was prescribed three medications
with a start date of 02/15/24.
3

Analysis Youth A was transferred from Wolverine Center to JDC on
02/25/24 and did not receive his medications until 03/14/24.
The agency Chief Administrator, Foster Care Program Supervisor,
and Staff 1 acknowledged they assumed that it was the
responsibility of Wolverine Center to transfer Youth A’s
medications to JDC. When they learned on 03/07/24 that Youth A
did not have his medications the Chief Administrator gave a
directive to staff to get the medications to JDC. Staff 1 reported
she spoke with the JDC Director who initially would not accept
medications from Wolverine Center but allowed a onetime
acceptance of the medications. The medications were delivered to
JDC by Wolverine Center staff on 03/14/24.
The agency did not ensure that Youth A’s medications were
delivered to JDC upon his discharge from Wolverine center.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan the recommendation is for
continuance of the regular license.
